thread.title: The man who keeps the doctors flying
thread.title_full: The man who keeps the doctors flying

author: Cherie von Hörchner
title: The man who keeps the doctors flying
text:
By Cherie von Hörchner Posted February 06, 2017 15:02:53 Map: Broken Hill 2880 
As outback jobs go, they don't come much more critical — maintaining the flight safety systems for the aircraft of the Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS). 
Broken Hill RFDS avionics engineer Blake Clair is one of a small team of technical experts that keeps the aeromedical service at the ready for remote emergencies. 
"We've got one of our older aircrafts, a Beechcraft King Air B200s," he said. 
"We bring them in every 200 flying hours for an inspection. 
"At the moment the guys have got the engine cowls off and they're looking at the hot sections, the interiors are out of the aircraft and there's a full avionics inspection being done on it and also an undercarriage and wing inspection. 
"We've got seven engineers here and all seven guys will be working on the aircraft." Photo: Aircraft maintenance experts work on RFDS plane in Broken Hill in far west NSW. (ABC Rural: Cherie von Hörchner) 
Mr Clair said he had to keep a look out for the 'unexpected' when performing inspections. 
"Nothing is typical and the defects you find from there can vary from blown light bulbs, a tyre being changed to a whole engine," he said. 
"The daily inspections are the only typical thing. 
"We can fit four aeroplanes in here. Comfortably, we'd probably have two in here … when we've had dust storms, we've managed to squeeze five in." From the land to the sky 
Although from a local station, Mr Clair said he knew little about the Royal Flying Doctor Service until he started working for them. 
"I didn't have a great knowledge of the RFDS before I got the job here," he said. 
"My family own a rural property — Limestone station, which is halfway between Broken Hill and Silverton. We run merino sheep out there and we've got a carob and olive orchard. 
"I probably should have thought about it a bit sooner." Gyrocopter is work in progress 
Mr Clair's interest in aviation goes well beyond the hangar. 
"I've got a good friend here who builds gyrocopters. I just started to build my own, which is a work in progress," he said. 
"The machine is probably a few months away from being complete and then hopefully I will learn to fly it after that. 
"Once you go for a fly in a gyro you either like it or you don't and, fortunately, I got hooked on it." 
Mr Clair said being able to use the gyrocopter on a farm is a bonus. 
"It's mainly for hobby purposes," he said. 
"It's not something I'll be flying everyday, like you see in some of the big stations that go mustering sheep and goats all weekend. 
"It'll get a small use on the property — mine might get used once or twice for mustering." Photo: Dirt strip landings no problem for RFDS medical planes. (Supplied: Royal Flying Doctor Service South-Eastern Section) Working in extremes 
Being an avionics engineer in the outback takes grit and some serious determination, as outback working conditions can be challenging. 
"In summer it's scorching hot," Mr Clair said. 
"There's not much airflow coming through the hangar. We've got a couple of air-coolers that you'll find me in front of." 
In winter, of course, the opposite applies, but Mr Clair said the team improvised to stay ahead of the elements, and on the job. 
"It's freezing cold (in winter). 
"You'll usually find some portable heaters sitting in the aeroplanes and someone curled up in a corner there."
